list.expr: sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(short_version) unless (sum(vm_app_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"} offset $__interval) by(short_version))
list.name: version change

description: Overview for cluster version of VictoriaLogs v1.22.0 or higher

panels.description: Shows total amount of log entries in the storage.
panels.title: Total log entries

panels.description: The total number of log entries ingested over the past 24 hours.
panels.title: Ingested logs 24h

panels.description: Shows the average ingestion rate of log entries.
panels.title: Insert req/s

panels.description:
Total amount of used disk space.
Accounts for all compressed log entries and index size.

See how to [control disk usage](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/#retention-by-disk-space-usage).
panels.title: Disk space usage

panels.description: Integer number of CPU cores available to the application. This value is automatically rounded down from fractional CPU quotas since the Go runtime requires integer concurrency limits. Fractional CPU units should be avoided for optimal performance. See [best practices](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/bestpractices/#kubernetes) documentation for more details.
panels.title: Available CPU

panels.description: See [latest releases](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/changelog/).
panels.title: Version

panels.description:
The cumulative number of log entries ingested over the last 24h. 

The size is calculated before compression.
panels.title: Ingested bytes 24h

panels.description: Shows the rate of HTTP read requests.
panels.title: Read req/s

panels.description:
The ratio between original data size and compressed data stored on disk. This metric excludes indexdb size. 

The ratio can go up or down as the system performs automatic maintenance and applies retention policies. For examples:
- Background merges: [Merges](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/#forced-merge) improve compression by combining data into larger, more efficiently compressed blocks
- Retention policies: When old data is deleted due to retention settings, the ratio changes as different time periods have varying compression characteristics
panels.title: Compression ratio

panels.description: Total system memory available to the application. This represents the system or container's memory capacity or limit, not the currently free memory.
panels.title: Available memory

targets.expr:
sum by (instance, version, tier) (
  label_set(
    vm_app_version{job=~"$job",instance=~"$instance_select"}
      and on(instance,version)
    vm_app_version{job=~"$job",instance=~"$instance_insert"} * 0 + 1,
    "tier","select,insert"
  )

or 
  label_set(
    vm_app_version{job=~"$job",instance=~"$instance_select"}
      unless on(instance,version)
    vm_app_version{job=~"$job",instance=~"$instance_insert"} * 0 + 1,
    "tier","select"
  )

or
  label_set(
    vm_app_version{job=~"$job",instance=~"$instance_insert"}
      unless on(instance,version)
    vm_app_version{job=~"$job",instance=~"$instance_select"} * 0 + 1,
    "tier","insert"
  )

or
  label_set(
    vm_app_version{job=~"$job",instance=~"$instance_storage"} * 0 + 1,
    "tier","storage"
  )
)

panels.description: Shows ingestion rate in number of log entries and bytes per second.
panels.title: Logs ingestion rate

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/insert` - [inserts](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/data-ingestion/)
* `/select` - [reads](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/querying/)
* `/metrics` - scraping of system metrics
panels.title: Requests rate

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/insert` - [inserts](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/data-ingestion/)
* `/select` - [reads](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/querying/)
* `/metrics` - scraping of system metrics
panels.title: Requests error rate

panels.description: The less time it takes is better.
panels.title: Query duration 0.99 quantile

panels.description:
Shows the amount of on-disk space occupied by all the data stored in the storage.

See how to [control disk usage](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/#retention-by-disk-space-usage).
panels.title: Disk space usage

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

panels.description: Shows the number of restarts per job. The chart can be useful to identify periodic process restarts and correlate them with potential issues or anomalies. Normally, processes shouldn't restart unless restart was inited by user. The reason of restarts should be figured out by checking the logs of each specific service.
panels.title: Restarts

panels.description:
The number of the new [log streams](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/keyconcepts/#stream-fields) created over the last 24h.

Prefer having as low churn rate as possible. 
See [How to determine which fields must be associated with log streams?](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/keyconcepts/#how-to-determine-which-fields-must-be-associated-with-log-streams)
panels.title: Log stream churn rate

panels.description: Flags explicitly set to non-default values

targets.expr: sum(flag{is_set="true", job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"}) by(job, instance, name, value)

panels.title: Non-default flags
Logs dropped for last 1h

panels.description:
Percentage of used memory (resident).
The application's performance will significantly degrade when memory usage is close to 100%.
panels.title: RSS memory % usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%
panels.title: RSS anonymous memory % usage ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows CPU pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).

The lower the better.
panels.title: CPU pressure

panels.description:
Shows memory pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).

The lower the better.
panels.title: Memory pressure

panels.description: Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer.
panels.title: Disk writes/reads ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of open file descriptors compared to the limit set in the OS.
Reaching the limit of open files can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the number of read/write syscalls such as read, pread, write, pwrite.
panels.title: Disk write/read calls ($instance)

panels.description:
Shows IO pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).

The lower the better.
panels.title: IO pressure

panels.description:
Shows the percent of CPU spent on garbage collection.

If % is high, then CPU usage can be decreased by changing GOGC to higher values. Increasing GOGC value will increase memory usage, and decrease CPU usage.

Try searching for keyword `GOGC` at https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/troubleshooting/
panels.title: CPU spent on GC ($instance)

panels.description: Shows the rate of allocations in memory. Sudden increase in allocations would mean increased pressure on Go Garbage Collector and can saturate CPU resources of the application.
panels.title: Memory allocations rate

panels.description:
Shows the time goroutines have spent in runnable state before actually running. The lower is better.

High values or values exceeding the threshold is usually a sign of            insufficient CPU resources or CPU throttling. 

Verify that service has enough CPU resources. Otherwise, the service could work unreliably with delays in processing.
panels.title: Go scheduling latency

panels.description:
- user: total CPU time spent in user space (app code)
- system: total CPU time spent in system/kernel space (e.g., syscalls)
- total: user + system

If system CPU rises while user % falls, suspect: disk bottlenecks, memory pressure and high GC overhead
panels.title: CPU Cores ($instance)

panels.description:
How much memory (RAM) the VictoriaLogs process is actually using, compared to its allowed container or system limit. See 'Memory Usage' panel for a detailed breakdown.

- Good: Below 70% most of the time, maybe spiking a bit under load.
- Bad: Above 90% for more than 5 minutes = risk of out-of-memory (OOM) kill.
panels.title: Physical memory usage ($instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the total number of time-based (daily) partitions in storage. The number typically grows over time as new data arrives and is partitioned by time periods. 

Excessive partition counts may indicate retention policy issues or very high data ingestion rates that could impact query performance.
panels.title: Partition Count (sum of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows disk space usage and limits for VictoriaLogs storage. Tracks current data usage against the configured retention limit or available disk space.

The red line indicates the space retention limit. When usage approaches this limit, older data will be automatically deleted. If the space retention limit (`-retention.maxDiskSpaceUsageBytes`) is not specified, the red line represents the maximum disk space. In that case, the storage will switch to read-only mode when the limit is reached.
panels.title: Disk ($instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the rate of incoming query requests by endpoint path. This metric tracks the query load on VictoriaLogs, including different query interfaces and internal operations. 

Higher rates indicate increased query activity from users or applications. Monitor for sudden spikes that might indicate new dashboards, automated queries, or potential performance issues. Sustained high rates may require scaling query processing capacity.
panels.title: HTTP request rate ($instance_storage)

panels.description: Shows the 99th percentile of HTTP request duration. This represents the time it takes for 99% of HTTP operations to complete. High values indicate slow ingestion/querying performance that could affect overall system throughput. Spikes may suggest storage bottlenecks, resource contention, or inefficient data processing.
panels.title: HTTP request duration 0.99 quantile (sum of $instance_storage)

panels.description: Shows ingestion rate in number of log entries and bytes per second.
panels.title: Logs ingestion rate

panels.description:
Shows the number of concurrent insert operations compared to the configured limit. 

High utilization near the limit may indicate ingestion bottlenecks. If current consistently approaches the limit, consider increasing the concurrency limit or optimizing ingestion performance. Sustained saturation can lead to insert request queuing and increased latency.
panels.title: Concurrent inserts (max of $instance)

panels.description:
Shows the number of log rows waiting to be written to storage, categorized by type. Pending rows indicate temporary queuing during ingestion. Consistently high values may suggest storage write bottlenecks or insufficient write capacity.

Pending rows are flushed in two ways:

- After a specific time period (typically 1 second)
- When the pending row size exceeds a threshold (typically 1.75 MB)
panels.title: Pending rows (sum of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
Displays the number of active message processors handling log ingestion. These processors parse and process incoming log messages before storage. The count typically correlates with the ingestion load.

If this number is unusually high or inflated (which is rare), check memory usage. It may indicate a heavy ingestion load or processing bottlenecks that could benefit from performance tuning.
panels.title: Message processors ($instance_storage)

panels.description: The number of new [log streams](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/keyconcepts/#stream-fields) created over the last 24 hours. Lower is better. See [How to determine which fields must be associated with log streams?](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/keyconcepts/#how-to-determine-which-fields-must-be-associated-with-log-streams)
panels.title: Streams churn rate 24h ($instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile of query execution duration. This represents the time it takes for 99% of queries to complete:

- High values indicate slow query performance that affects user experience. 
- Spikes may suggest complex queries, resource contention, or inefficient indexes. Monitor for trends that could indicate degrading performance.
panels.title: Query duration 0.99 quantile (max of $instance_storage))

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile of log rows read per query. This metric indicates query scan efficiency and data volume processed. 

High values may suggest broad queries that scan large amounts of data, potentially impacting performance. Consider adding filters, time ranges, or optimizing query patterns if values are consistently high.
panels.title: Rows read/query 0.99 quantile (sum of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the rate of incoming query requests by endpoint path. This metric tracks the query load on VictoriaLogs, including different query interfaces and internal operations. 

Higher rates indicate increased query activity from users or applications. Monitor for sudden spikes that might indicate new dashboards, automated queries, or potential performance issues. Sustained high rates may require scaling query processing capacity.
panels.title: Query requests rate (sum of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile of query execution duration. This represents the time it takes for 99% of queries to complete:

- High values indicate slow query performance that affects user experience. 
- Spikes may suggest complex queries, resource contention, or inefficient indexes. Monitor for trends that could indicate degrading performance.
panels.title: Query request duration 0.99 quantile ($instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile of log streams accessed per query. The higher, the better.

This panel answers the question: "How many streams did your query use to fetch logs?" Using a [stream filter](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/logsql/#stream-filter) is one of the most common and efficient ways to fetch logs.
panels.title: Used streams/query 0.99 quantile (max of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the number of ongoing merge operations by storage type. Smaller parts are continuously merged into larger ones for optimization. 

Active merges are normal background operations that improve query performance and storage efficiency. High numbers of active merges for 'storage/inmemory', 'storage/small' types are expected, while sustained high activity might indicate heavy write load or storage optimization in progress.
panels.title: Part count (sum of $instance)

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile of bytes read per query. This metric indicates the amount of data processed during queries and correlates with query performance.

- If the number of rows read is high but the bytes read is low, the query is efficient.
- High byte values may indicate queries scanning large amounts of data, potentially affecting performance and resource usage. Consider optimizing queries using more specific filters (e.g., [stream filter](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victorialogs/logsql/#stream-filter), only necessary rows) or narrower time ranges to reduce data volume.
panels.title: Bytes read/query 0.99 quantile (sum of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile duration of merge operations by storage type. Merge operations combine smaller storage parts into larger ones for optimization. 

Normal merge durations vary by storage type and data volume. Consistently high durations may indicate storage performance issues, high write load, or insufficient resources for background operations. Monitor for trends that could impact overall system performance.
panels.title: Merge duration 0.99 percentile (max of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile of data volume processed during merge operations by storage type. 

This metric indicates the scale of background storage optimization activities. Larger merge sizes generally improve storage efficiency but require more resources. Consistently high values may indicate heavy write loads or large storage parts that need optimization. Monitor correlation with merge duration for performance insights.
panels.title: Merge bytes 0.99 percentile (max of $instance_storage)

panels.description:
How much memory (RAM) the VictoriaLogs process is actually using, compared to its allowed container or system limit. See 'Memory Usage' panel for a detailed breakdown.

- Good: Below 70% most of the time, maybe spiking a bit under load.
- Bad: Above 90% for more than 5 minutes = risk of out-of-memory (OOM) kill.
panels.title: Physical memory usage ($instance_insert)

panels.description:
Shows the rate of incoming query requests by endpoint path. This metric tracks the query load on VictoriaLogs, including different query interfaces and internal operations. 

Higher rates indicate increased query activity from users or applications. Monitor for sudden spikes that might indicate new dashboards, automated queries, or potential performance issues. Sustained high rates may require scaling query processing capacity.
panels.title: HTTP request rate ($instance_storage)

panels.description: Shows the 99th percentile of insert operation duration. This represents the time it takes for 99% of insert operations to complete. High values indicate slow ingestion performance that could affect overall system throughput. Spikes may suggest storage bottlenecks, resource contention, or inefficient data processing.
panels.title: HTTP request duration 0.99 quantile (sum of $instance_insert)

panels.description: Shows ingestion rate in number of log entries and bytes per second.
panels.title: Logs ingestion rate

panels.description:
Displays the number of active message processors handling log ingestion. These processors parse and process incoming log messages before storage. The count typically correlates with the ingestion load.

If this number is unusually high or inflated (which is rare), check memory usage. It may indicate a heavy ingestion load or processing bottlenecks that could benefit from performance tuning.
panels.title: Message processors ($instance_insert)

panels.description:
Shows the number of concurrent insert operations compared to the configured limit. 

High utilization near the limit may indicate ingestion bottlenecks. If current consistently approaches the limit, consider increasing the concurrency limit or optimizing ingestion performance. Sustained saturation can lead to insert request queuing and increased latency.
panels.title: Concurrent inserts ($instance)

panels.description:
How much memory (RAM) the VictoriaLogs process is actually using, compared to its allowed container or system limit. See 'Memory Usage' panel for a detailed breakdown.

- Good: Below 70% most of the time, maybe spiking a bit under load.
- Bad: Above 90% for more than 5 minutes = risk of out-of-memory (OOM) kill.
panels.title: Physical memory usage ($instance_select)

panels.description:
Shows the rate of incoming query requests by endpoint path. This metric tracks the query load on VictoriaLogs, including different query interfaces and internal operations. 

Higher rates indicate increased query activity from users or applications. Monitor for sudden spikes that might indicate new dashboards, automated queries, or potential performance issues. Sustained high rates may require scaling query processing capacity.
panels.title: HTTP request rate ($instance_select)

panels.description:
Shows the 99th percentile of query execution duration. This represents the time it takes for 99% of queries to complete:

- High values indicate slow query performance that affects user experience. 
- Spikes may suggest complex queries, resource contention, or inefficient indexes. Monitor for trends that could indicate degrading performance.
panels.title: HTTP request duration 0.99 quantile ($instance_select)

panels.description:
Shows the number of concurrent select (query) operations compared to the configured limit.

High utilization near the limit may indicate query bottlenecks or insufficient query processing capacity.

If it's consistently high while CPU usage remains low, consider increasing the concurrency limit (`-search.maxConcurrentRequests`) or optimizing query performance to support more concurrent users.
panels.title: Concurrent queries ($instance)

title: VictoriaLogs - cluster (VM)
